# ZeroFrame API

[ZeroFrame API Reference](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/)
> ZeroFrame is an API that allows ZeroNet websites to interact with the ZeroNet daemon. It allows sites to save/retrieve files, publish changes and many other things. A copy of the library is included at js/ZeroFrame.js whenever a new site is created.
## Client-side
Let's follow the communications of a call to the back-end.  If your site does the following:  

```javascript
    page = new ZeroFrame()
    page.cmd("wrapperPermissionAdd", "NOSANDBOX", function(res) {
        if (!res.error) page.cmd("wrapperReload")
    })
```

you first get an instance of ZeroFrame.  You then call the asynchronous `cmd` method, which has two required parameters, the command and its parameters, and an optional response handler.  

This adds the wrapper nonce and an incremental message id resulting in this message being sent to the parent window:

```json
{
  cmd: cmd,
  params: params,
  wrapper_nonce: wrapper_nonce,
  id, next_message_id
}
```
to the parent window, which is the wrapper for the IFrame containing your site, effectively using this:

  window.parent.[postMessage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage)(message, '*')

If you have a response handler (callback), it is put on a map indexed by the message id.  

The Wrapper class is defined in [src/UI/media/Wrapper.coffee](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/media/Wrapper.coffee@master).  Running ZN in DEBUG mode compiles this Coffee Script into Javascript, and put it in the all.js, which is loaded by [Wrapper.html](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/template/wrapper.html@master), the template used to wrap the site's page with an IFrame.

### Wrapper class (coffee)

This Coffee Script, with 704 lines, is the heart of the client side of the framework.  We continue our adventure with this line:

```
  window.addEventListener("message", @onMessageInner, false)```

After some checks, onMessageInner passes the message to:

```
  handleMessage: (message) =>```

This contains an `if` with a list of `else if` statements that primarily capture UI oriented commands that are executed client-side.  In our case, `wrapperPermissionAdd` does match an `if`, and that calls `actionPermissionAdd(message)` in Wrapper.coffee.  This then calls the server via WebSockets for `permissionDetails`, which is then used to as the user in the UI to confirm adding the new permission.  If the user consents, it calls the server again with `permissionAdd`.   

### Invoking the server

Wrapper.handleMessage is really acting as a facade that can convert simple commands into operations that invoke the server multiple times, or perhaps do client-only execution.  However, if there is no match, the final `else` sends this to the server, **giving the UI the potential to invoke any command in the server in addition to those identified in the Wrapper**.  

```javascript
  @ws.send(message) # Pass message to websocket
```
This `ws` was previously instantiated wtih 

```javascript
  @ws = new ZeroWebsocket(ws_url)
```

defined in [src/UI/media/lib/ZeroWebsocket.coffee](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/media/lib/ZeroWebsocket.coffee@master).

which finally sends the message to the server:

```javascript
  if @connected
    @ws.send(JSON.stringify(message))```

where, this time, `ws` is a [WebSocket](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket). What URL was passed when this WebSocket was instantiated?  That is defined in Wrapper.coffee:

```javascript
ws_url = proto.ws + ":" + origin.replace(proto.http+":", "") + "/ZeroNet-Internal/Websocket?wrapper_key=" + window.wrapper_key
window.wrapper = new Wrapper(ws_url)```

which I quickly pulled debugging this page.  

"ws://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroNet-Internal/Websocket?wrapper_key=e988d7e7ca8e...d0"

___
SIDE OBSERVATION: if I refreshed the page, the wrapper_key remained the same.  But, when I debugged a different tab, that number was different.  
 
gitcenter@zeroid.bit [clarified](/1KmgpXc9BLFxw1ccGANYVzvDh3YG95tSe3/?Topic:1566178696_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXqZqP7n#comment_18_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di):
"wrapper_key is unique to site. It's generated randomly each time you download a site and is used to make Websocket connections secure."
___

ZeroNet is bootstrapped with a user modifiable list of trackers that it uses to locate peers of content.  It then talks to these peers.

The Bootstrapper plugin can also discover peers using cjdns and yggdrasil in a local LAN or mesh topology, adding tracker server like features to your ZeroNet client.  Kaffie has a [tutorial on cjdns](/1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8/?Post:51:Using+CJDNS+with+ZeroNet).  

## Encryption

per gitcenter@zeroid.bit [in ZeroTalk](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1566241934_13ifSHXbs2RtyHF4qkn4GrJ3krWEAAGmka/JavaScript+Tor#comment_625_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): 
___
ZeroNet itself can't be encrypted -- it's just an application. What you are asking is whether ZeroNet protocol is encrypted. Actually, it can be both encrypted and raw, depending on:

- ZeroNet tries connecting to peers and does a handshake, then;
- If the remote peer supports encryption, the protocol is encrypted;
- Otherwise, ZeroNet proceeds with unencrypted protocol.

If you set any config options manually, it's a bit more difficult.

- If disable_encryption config option is set, the protocol is always raw;
- Otherwise, ZeroNet tries connecting to peers and does a handshake, then;
- If the remote peer supports encryption, the protocol is encrypted;
- Otherwise, if force_encryption config option is set, ZeroNet disconnects from the peer;
- In case the peer doesn't support encryption but there is no force_encryption option, ZeroNet proceeds with unencrypted protocol.

So if you want to be very secure, you can use force_encryption option.

When ZN boots up, it begins configured to support a default homepage even if it cannot connect to the network. This is loaded when the URL is just the base "/".  While it defaults to the ZeroHello site, this can be overridden via the --homepage parameter.  

```python3
self.parser.add_argument('--homepage', help='Web interface Homepage', 
default='1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D', metavar='address')
```

To help with this bootstrapping, the ZeroHello app is included in the default data folder.  The ZeroName site is also in this folder, along with preconfigured sites.json and users.json.  The rest of the demo zites on the left sidebar are loaded via the network when the user clicks on them to activate.

# ZeroFrame API

[ZeroFrame API Reference](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/)
> ZeroFrame is an API that allows ZeroNet websites to interact with the ZeroNet daemon. It allows sites to save/retrieve files, publish changes and many other things. A copy of the library is included at js/ZeroFrame.js whenever a new site is created.

Let's follow the communications of a call to the back-end.  If your site does the following:  

```javascript
    page = new ZeroFrame()
    page.cmd("wrapperPermissionAdd", "NOSANDBOX", function(res) {
        if (!res.error) page.cmd("wrapperReload")
    })
```

you first get an instance of ZeroFrame.  You then call the asynchronous `cmd` method, which has two required parameters, the command and its parameters, and an optional response handler.  

This adds the wrapper nonce and an incremental message id resulting in this message being sent to the parent window:

```json
{
  cmd: cmd,
  params: params,
  wrapper_nonce: wrapper_nonce,
  id, next_message_id
}
```
to the parent window, which is the wrapper for the IFrame containing your site, effectively using this:

  window.parent.[postMessage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage)(message, '*')

If you have a response handler (callback), it is put on a map indexed by the message id.  

The Wrapper class is defined in [src/UI/media/Wrapper.coffee](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/media/Wrapper.coffee@master).  Running ZN in DEBUG mode compiles this Coffee Script into Javascript, and put it in the all.js, which is loaded by [Wrapper.html](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/template/wrapper.html@master), the template used to wrap the site's page with an IFrame.

### Wrapper class (coffee)

This Coffee Script, with 704 lines, is the heart of the client side of the framework.  We continue our adventure with this line:

```
  window.addEventListener("message", @onMessageInner, false)```

After some checks, onMessageInner passes the message to:

```
  handleMessage: (message) =>```

This contains an `if` with a list of `else if` statements that primarily capture UI oriented commands that are executed client-side.  In our case, `wrapperPermissionAdd` does match an `if`, and that calls `actionPermissionAdd(message)` in Wrapper.coffee.  This then calls the server via WebSockets for `permissionDetails`, which is then used to as the user in the UI to confirm adding the new permission.  If the user consents, it calls the server again with `permissionAdd`.   

### Invoking the server

Wrapper.handleMessage is really acting as a facade that can convert simple commands into operations that invoke the server multiple times, or perhaps do client-only execution.  However, if there is no match, the final `else` sends this to the server, **giving the UI the potential to invoke any command in the server in addition to those identified in the Wrapper**.  

```javascript
  @ws.send(message) # Pass message to websocket
```
This `ws` was previously instantiated wtih 

```javascript
  @ws = new ZeroWebsocket(ws_url)
```

defined in [src/UI/media/lib/ZeroWebsocket.coffee](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/src/Ui/media/lib/ZeroWebsocket.coffee@master).

which finally sends the message to the server:

```javascript
  if @connected
    @ws.send(JSON.stringify(message))```

where, this time, `ws` is a [WebSocket](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket). What URL was passed when this WebSocket was instantiated?  That is defined in Wrapper.coffee:

```javascript
ws_url = proto.ws + ":" + origin.replace(proto.http+":", "") + "/ZeroNet-Internal/Websocket?wrapper_key=" + window.wrapper_key
window.wrapper = new Wrapper(ws_url)```

which I quickly pulled debugging this page.  

"ws://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroNet-Internal/Websocket?wrapper_key=e988d7e7ca8e...d0"

SIDE OBSERVATION: if I refreshed the page, the wrapper_key remained the same.  But, when I debugged a different tab, that number was different.  
 
This takes us to the server side.

# Sandbox

ZeroNet wraps every page served in a site by an IFrame, and then uses its sandbox attribute to limit what it can do, effectively sandboxing zites.  

This breaks various types of sites, including [simple static Angular sites](/1KmgpXc9BLFxw1ccGANYVzvDh3YG95tSe3/?Topic:1565995454_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXqZqP7n/ISSUE+CORS+prevents+site+from+loading).  To live a happy life in ZeroNet, these apps can request that the user grant the NOSANDBOX permission to the site with this code:

```javascript
    page = new ZeroFrame()
    page.cmd("wrapperPermissionAdd", "NOSANDBOX", function(res) {
        if (!res.error) page.cmd("wrapperReload")
    })
```

If a user visits the site, but hasn't yet granted the NOSANDBOX permission, they'll get this message:

![NOSANDBOX.png](img/NOSANDBOX.png)

If they grant it, this line is added to their sites.json:

```
  "permissions": ["NOSANDBOX"],
```

and they are no longer prompted for it.  

## NOSANDBOX permission

The code in py3 branch Aug 2019 only shows one impact to this permission:

```python
        if "NOSANDBOX" in site.settings["permissions"]:
            sandbox_permissions += " allow-same-origin"
```

which then gets passed to the sandbox element in the `<iframe>` tag via the rendering using the `src/Ui/template/wrapper.html` template.  

Here is the IFrame line from the template:

<iframe src='about:blank' id='inner-iframe' sandbox="allow-forms allow-scripts allow-top-navigation allow-popups allow-modals allow-presentation allow-pointer-lock {**sandbox_permissions**}" allowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" oallowfullscreen="true" msallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

And the result in the browser for a site with NOSANDBOX permission:

<iframe src='about:blank' id='inner-iframe' sandbox="allow-forms allow-scripts allow-top-navigation allow-popups allow-modals allow-presentation allow-pointer-lock  **allow-same-origin**" allowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" oallowfullscreen="true" msallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

and an iframe from a site that does not have the NOSANDBOX permission (this wiki):

<iframe src='about:blank' id='inner-iframe' sandbox="allow-forms allow-scripts allow-top-navigation allow-popups allow-modals allow-presentation allow-pointer-lock " allowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" oallowfullscreen="true" msallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

A javascript variable is also set so the site can inquire on whether or not the user granted the permission, and perhaps displaying a notification otherwise.

```javascript
permissions = ["NOSANDBOX"]
```

According to [w3schools](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_iframe_sandbox.asp), allow-same-origin "allows the iframe content to be treated as being from the same origin".  

## Impacts

One of the reasons why `NOSANDBOX` permission is all-caps and marked is dangerous is that sandbox traversal becomes easy. Consider the following PoC:

```javascript
window.parent.zeroframe.cmd("siteList", [], console.log.bind(console));
```

You'll see that site list is logged to the console, which lets sites deanonymize you. Another example:

```javascript
window.parent.zeroframe.cmd("setConfig", ["open_browser", "cmd && rem %s"]);
window.parent.zeroframe.cmd("serverShutdown", [true]);
```

Running this code results in ZeroNet restart and a shell appearing instead of ZeroNet console. This means that an attacker can run any software on your computer, possibly stealing private keys and setting up a data locker.

That's why using NOSANDBOX is not recommended.
